Problem:
Consider a complex function scenario where \\( z(t) \\) evolves according to \\( \\frac{dz}{dt} = i\\omega z \\), with \\( \\omega \\) being a constant frequency parameter. We investigate the impact of applying a Fourier transform \\( F(z) \\) defined by \\( F(z)(\\omega) = \\int_{-\\infty}^{\\infty} z(t) e^{-i \\omega t} dt \\).

After observing the outcome of the Fourier transform \\( F(z)(\\omega) \\) at t = T, can we precisely determine the original function \\( z(0) \\)?
Explanation: The Fourier transform is invertible under suitable conditions on \\( z(t) \\) (such as being square-integrable over its domain) and can thus be perfectly inverted to retrieve \\( z(0) \\) from \\( F(z)(\\omega) \\) at any time T given that the evolution does not change the frequency content.
